skill.name: enact/hello-brainfuck
skill.description: A greeting tool written entirely in Brainfuck - the esoteric programming language with only 8 commands.
skill.summary: A Brainfuck esolang greeting tool demonstrating minimalist esoteric programming
skill.author: EnactProtocol

security_audit.summary: Static scanner flagged 17 external_command patterns and 4 weak_crypto patterns. Manual review confirms all are false positives. The external_command detections are Brainfuck language syntax (>, <, +, -, ., ,, [, ]) documented in SKILL.md, not shell commands. The weak_crypto detections are text containing 'Brainfuck' misidentified by the scanner. This skill contains only documentation and a Brainfuck source file - no executable code or security-sensitive operations.

content.value_statement: Brainfuck is an esoteric programming language with only 8 commands. This skill provides a complete Hello World implementation demonstrating minimalist code that outputs greetings using pure ASCII manipulation.
actual_capabilities: Executes Brainfuck code to output greeting messages
Returns structured JSON output with the greeting message
Demonstrates Brainfuck esolang syntax and programming concepts
Provides educational examples of Brainfuck program structure
limitations: Only outputs predefined greeting messages from static Brainfuck code
Does not accept user input for dynamic message generation
Limited to Brainfuck interpreter functionality within timeout constraints
No file system or network access capabilities

use_cases.title: Learn Brainfuck Syntax
use_cases.description: New programmers explore the Brainfuck esolang by examining how a complete program uses only 8 commands to produce output.

use_cases.title: Demonstrate Esoteric Languages
use_cases.description: Educators show Brainfuck as an example of a Turing-complete language with minimal instruction set for teaching computation concepts.

use_cases.title: Tool Registry Showcase
use_cases.description: Developers add a playful example to their tool registry demonstrating that even impractical languages have practical applications.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Greeting
prompt_templates.prompt: Run enact/hello-brainfuck to get a greeting
prompt_templates.scenario: Simple request to execute the Brainfuck hello world program

prompt_templates.title: Brainfuck Example
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how enact/hello-brainfuck works and what it outputs
prompt_templates.scenario: Learning about the skill's functionality and output format

prompt_templates.title: Esolang Demonstration
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the Brainfuck skill and explain how the program produces its output using only the 8 Brainfuck commands
prompt_templates.scenario: Understanding Brainfuck programming concepts through execution

prompt_templates.title: Compare Outputs
prompt_templates.prompt: Run enact/hello-brainfuck and explain the JSON response structure it returns
prompt_templates.scenario: Examining the skill's output format for integration purposes

best_practices: Use this skill for educational purposes to understand minimalist programming languages
Review the source hello.bf file to see how complex output is produced with simple commands
Combine with documentation reading skills to understand Brainfuck esolang principles
anti_patterns: Do not expect this skill to accept dynamic input or generate custom messages
Avoid assuming this skill has network or file system access
Do not use this skill for production code - it is an educational demonstration

faq.question: What is Brainfuck?
faq.answer: Brainfuck is an esoteric programming language created in 1993 by Urban MÃ¼ller. It uses only 8 commands and is designed to be minimal while remaining Turing-complete.

faq.question: What does this skill actually do?
faq.answer: It executes a pre-written Brainfuck program that outputs 'Hello from Brainfuck!' and returns the message in JSON format.

faq.question: Can I modify the greeting message?
faq.answer: No. This skill runs a fixed Brainfuck program. To change the output, you would need to modify the underlying hello.bf file.

faq.question: Is this skill safe to use?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill runs Brainfuck code with a 30-second timeout and has no network or file system access beyond its defined operation.

faq.question: What are the 8 Brainfuck commands?
faq.answer: The commands are: > (move right), < (move left), + (increment), - (decrement), . (output), , (input), [ (jump forward if zero), ] (jump back if non-zero).

faq.question: Why does this skill exist?
faq.answer: Every tool registry deserves at least one Brainfuck program. It demonstrates that even impractical-looking languages have practical implementations and can teach fundamental programming concepts.
